articles.title: 'Helene One Year of Healing,' celebrates community
articles.author: Laura Denon
articles.summary: It's been one year since Hurricane Helene struck Transylvania County and the rest of Western North Carolina. The community event 'Helene One Year of Healing 2025' was held at the Brevard Music Center on Saturday, Sept. 27 to mark the anniversary.

articles.title: Europe must step up efforts to protect environment: report
articles.author: Camille BAS-WOHLERT AFP
articles.summary: Europe is a world leader in the fight against climate change but must do more to protect its environment, the EU's environment agency warns. "Significant progress has been made in reducing greenhouse gas emissions and air pollution, but the overall state of Europe's environment is not good," it says.

articles.title: Europe must step up efforts to protect environment: report
articles.author: Camille Bas-Wohlert Afp
articles.summary: Extreme weather is a growing problem for Europe, report says. A heatwave that hit France in July was a recent example of such weather in the region.       in July.  in the report  in which it was said that extreme weather is growing in Europe.

articles.title: These Australians are homeless with a house
articles.author: Jayden O'Neill
articles.summary: Aboriginal people in Tennant Creek live in overcrowded makeshift shelters with no running water or electricity. The average maximum temperature across the year is 32.1C. From 1994 to 2024, an average of 142 days each year reached 35C. The Northern Territory has 12 times the national rate of homelessness. 87 per cent of those homeless are Indigenous.

articles.title: Climate change is taking a real toll on young people's mental health
articles.author: Marjorie Collins
articles.summary: The first National Climate Risk Assessment (NCRA) forecast doomsday scenarios for Australia due to climate change. The government set emission levels aimed at averting warming above 1.5 degrees by 2035. The cost of these changes is debated across business and political forums and in the media. What is less debated is the impact of climate change on everyday Australians' mental health. Children born in 2021 are expected to experience seven times more climate-related disasters in their lifetime than previous generations. Over 67 per cent of young Australians report that climate concerns negatively impact their mental health, and half of those aged 16-25 report negative emotions like sadness and anxiety. Rural and regional Australians are disproportionately affected by

articles.title: Climate change is taking a real toll on young people's mental health
articles.author: Marjorie Collins
articles.summary: The first National Climate Risk Assessment (NCRA) has predicted doomsday scenarios for Australia due to climate change. There will be more frequent and severe heatwaves, droughts, and bushfires, and rising sea levels due to the effects of climate change in Australia.

articles.title: Climate change is taking a real toll on young people's mental health
articles.author: Marjorie Collins
articles.summary: The first National Climate Risk Assessment (NCRA) has warned of the negative effects of climate change on Australia. The government has set emission levels aimed at averting warming above 1.5 degrees by 2035. Many young people are worried about climate change. Rural and regional Australians are disproportionately affected by climate change and have a higher suicide rate.

articles.title: Donald Trump's 'climate hoax' comments belong to a well-resourced playbook landing on Australia's shores
articles.author: Jess Davis
articles.summary: Donald Trump called climate change "the greatest con job ever perpetrated on the world". In the US, researchers tracked how dark money and fossil fuel interests fund a network of climate denial think tanks. In Australia, it's even harder to track these groups, but they already have their tentacles entwined in fomenting opposition to the energy transition.

articles.title: Nigel Farage's wild claims slapped down in bombshell poll
articles.author: The Mirror
articles.summary: Two-thirds of people in a new poll believe global warming is man-made. Six in 10 think it will threaten their families' futures. More than 45,300 people took part in the poll of more than 45.300 people.

articles.title: Rare deluge in Kolkata tied to climate change, say experts
articles.author: Team Mp
articles.summary: 251.4 mm of rain fell in less than 24 hours in Kolkata from Monday night to Tuesday morning. The downpour was the heaviest since 1986 and the sixth-highest single-day rainfall in 137 years. Global ocean warming is altering weather in India.

articles.title: WATCH: Viewers have 'never been more excited' for 'epic' thriller sequel after trailer drops
articles.author: Allen
articles.summary: Greenland 2: Migration is a new survival thriller starring Gerard Butler, Morena Baccarin and Roman Griffin Davis. The sequel picks up from the first film and follows John and the Garrity family as they navigate the harsh new realities of their devastated world following a comet that almost wiped out humanity.

articles.title: Effects of Atlantic drought could increase damage during hurricane season
articles.author: The Canadian Press
articles.summary: This summer's drought could have wide-ranging impacts as the Atlantic hurricane season continues through to the end of November. Droughts can cause major damage long term and in the short term a severe period of drought can weaken tree roots and dry out soils. Hurricane season has been relatively quiet so far this year, though experts say things could pick up through October.

articles.title: West Bengal Gears Up for Torrential Rain: Emergency Measures in Place
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The West Bengal government has taken steps in anticipation of heavy rainfall in early October. The IMD has forecasted the development of a low-pressure area over the Bay of Bengal, prompting advisories against maritime activities. Strong winds and rough seas are expected, and precautionary measures are essential for the safety of the coastal communities.

articles.title: ‘Trump S–ts the Bed': Internet Explodes After Donald Trump's Unhinged Claim He Can Predict the Future
articles.summary: President Donald Trump was speaking at the UN General Assembly last week. He called climate change a 'green scam' and said 'countries will fail' if they don't get away from it. He has spent his first eight months in office dismantling the Environmental Protection Agency, clean energy programs, and environmental regulations.

articles.title: Vietnam Braces for Impact as Typhoon Bualoi Threatens Central Coast
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Typhoon Bualoi is approaching Vietnam's central coast. It is the tenth typhoon to threaten the country in 2025. Vietnam's meteorology agency warned of the storm's rapid movement and its potential to unleash a combination of natural disasters. The typhoon's earlier impact on the Philippines resulted in widespread mudslides and floods.

articles.title: Agriculture, fisheries lose over P1 billion from typhoons
articles.author: The Philippine Star
articles.summary: Damage to the agriculture and fisheries sectors from three recent typhoons and heavy rains brought by the southwest monsoon has risen to over P1 billion. Most of the losses are concentrated in Cagayan Valley, especially in agriculture and fishing sectors.

Surrounded by a ring of snow-capped mountains, the imposing glacier seemed immutable. Its front, extending three kilometers wide and 50 meters high, loomed heavily into the water, where slabs of pack ice floated. Eventually, a darker color appeared: A group of walruses were resting, occasionally raising their long tusks. Nothing seemed to disturb the calm and beauty of the Arctic. Tourists and their guide, Oliver Walberg, facing the Oscar II Land, northwest of Isfjorden, in Svalbard, on May 30, 2025. In reality, this majestic landscape was neither still nor silent. On this day in May, the icebergs, streaked with blue veins and honeycomb-like pockets, were cracking under the bright sun. From time to time, blocks broke off and masses of ice flipped over. At a latitude of 78°, just 1,000 kilometers from the geographic North Pole, the Svalbard archipelago, part of Norway, is the fastest-warming place on Earth. articles.author: Audrey Garric
articles.summary: The Norwegian archipelago of Svalbard has warmed by 4°C over the past 30 years. Landslides and thawing permafrost threaten the population, whose way of life is highly greenhouse gas-intensive. At a latitude of 78°, just 1,000 km from the geographic North Pole, the Svalberg is the fastest-warming place on Earth.

articles.title: Agri damage hits P1. 38B
articles.author: The Manila Times
articles.summary: Tropical cyclones Mirasol, Nando and Opong and the southwest monsoon or habagat caused agriculture damage of P1.38 billion. This includes 47,723 hectares of farmland across the Cordillera Administrative Region, Ilocos and Cagayan Valley.

articles.title: Floating nests and decoys: how fairy terns are being charmed back to Port Phillip Bay
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Small seabirds are not faring well along Australia's south-eastern coastline, but there is hope for their resurgence thanks to some novel tactics used to repel them.    - i.e. the use of new techniques to reposition the birds.

articles.title: Changing the narrative of climate loss and damage ahead of COP30
articles.author: Tahmina Hadi
articles.summary: At COP30 this year, developing and least developed countries should take a strong stand against the delaying tactics of developed countries on climate commitments. Developed countries are reluctant to commit to addressing climate change-induced losses and damages due to their historical responsibility for emissions, the associated financial burden, and fears of compensation and legal liability. Less than 10% of global climate finance is allocated to adaptation efforts. Rural households in Bangladesh spend almost US$2 billion annually on repairing damage caused by climate change.

articles.title: New report ranks states on climate-related health risks, clean energy policies • Michigan Advance
articles.author: Nada Hassanein
articles.summary: Vermont, New York, Washington, New Jersey and Maine have the best combination of relatively low environmental risks and robust environmental policies. West Virginia, Kentucky, Louisiana, Florida and Mississippi ranked lowest on the 50-state scorecard produced by the Commonwealth Fund. Nevada, New Mexico and Arizona faced the greatest extreme heat-driven health risks. Alaska and Hawaii ranked highest in air quality.

articles.title: Winning Over Australia's Most Controversial Bird: A Guide
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: The peak of the swooping season for magpies is this weekend and into next week. Professor Darryl Jones is an ecologist and professor of ecology at Griffith University in Queensland. Australia's Magpie Alert map has recorded 2,753 swoops and 295 injuries this year. Only 10 per cent of the birds attack people and only when there are babies in their nests.

articles.title: Why crickets are as good as a thermometer
articles.author: CBS News
articles.summary: The chirping of crickets in the backyard is an accurate way to tell the temperature. Robert Krulwich and puppeteer Barnaby Dixon explain the mathematical formula for it. It's based on the Pythagorean Theory of Phenomenon.

articles.title: Vietnam: Thousands Evacuated Ahead of Typhoon Bualoi
articles.summary: Typhoons Bualoi and Ragasa have devastated the Philippines and Vietnam. Warming oceans act as fuel for stronger tropical cyclones. The increasing frequency and intensity of typhoons erodes the resilience of coastal communities. Vietnam, with its coastline facing the South China Sea, is particularly vulnerable.

articles.title: 2025 Arctic Sea Ice Minimum Nearly Half A Million Square Kilometers More Than 2007
articles.author: Guest Blogger
articles.summary: In the late 2000s, experts and climate bedwetters warned the late summer Arctic sea ice would disappear already by 2015, but it hasn't. This year's sea ice extent reached its low point of 4.602 million square kilometers on September 10th. It's more than 1.2 million square km greater than in 2012 and half a million km more than 2007.

articles.title: ‘I couldn't look': European farmers on losing crops as the industry collides with worsening drought
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Annual drought losses across Europe could reach €17.5bn. Shipping and power generation are also being affected by low water levels due to global heating and low temperatures.    i.e. droughts are affecting shipping, power generation and water supplies.

articles.title: DOMINICAN REPUBLIC RAINFALL
articles.author: ob AL CJ
articles.summary: Dominican Republic on alert for tropical cyclone. 4,990 people have been displaced and evacuated, three roads have been affected, 19 communities are cut off, and three bridges have been damaged. The Emergency Operations Center (EOC) has issued alerts for 11 provinces on yellow alert and eight on green alert.

articles.title: Bill Maher Shares Blunt Prediction About the 2028 Presidential Election

articles.summary: the high of 84F. Winds NE at 5 to 10 mph (30 km/h).    for the rest of the day.  for Griffin, GA.   in the evening.  in Griffin, Georgia, 30 m/  for today.

articles.title: Trump officials shut off funding for climate adaptation centers
articles.author: The Washington Post
articles.summary: A third of the U.S. Geological Survey's Climate Adaptation Science Centers are expected to wind down and possibly close after Sept. 30, according to the Geological Survey. The center is called the "Climate Adaptation Research Center" and it's located at the USGS's headquarters.

articles.title: FRENCH CONNECTION: Sunny days, keeps the word away
articles.author: Diana French
articles.summary: It's a sunny day in Williams Lake. I feel sorry for politicians who do nothing to stop genocide taking place in Palestine and the Sudan. Climate change is raising havoc around the world. In 2025, BC's wildfire season was ranked the second worst on record in Canada for both carbon emissions and area burned.

articles.title: Labor's Climate Plan Is All Thoughts And Prayers
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The government accepts the Climate Change Authority's 2035 emissions targets, but refuses to stop old growth logging. The report found that protecting native forests, reducing deforestation, and increasing environmental plantings are essential to cutting emissions. Climate Minister Chris Bowen dismissed the report as "commentary". Agriculture Minister Murray Watt confirmed that Labor has no intention of ending old-growth logging in Tasmania.

articles.title: When does the time change in 2025? Daylight saving time could end permanently
articles.author: Alexis Simmerman
articles.summary: This year, daylight saving time began on March 9 and will end on Sunday, Nov. 2. Time will fall back one hour from 2 a.m. to 1 a. m. in the 48 states that observe it. This year the autumnal equinox was on Monday, Sept 22. The new season arrives between Sept 21 and Sept 24 each year.

articles.title: Category 5 Hurricane Humberto Threatens Caribbean (2025)
articles.summary: Hurricane Humberto intensifies to 260 kph on September 27, 2025. There will be a 60% increase in the frequency of Category 4 and 5 hurricanes in the Atlantic basin over the next decade, fueled by rising sea temperatures. In South Florida, emergency director Jaime Hernández voiced a concern that residents are not adequately preparing for the upcoming hurricane season. People become desensitized by repeated warnings and they focus on short-term convenience over long-term safety. The problem is compounded by the fact that many communities haven't fully recovered from previous storms, leaving residents financially and emotionally drained.

articles.title: Chinese researchers identify new "geochemical switch" regulating Earth's Climate
articles.author: People Daily
articles.summary: Shifts in marine sulfate concentrations can flip the way that methane is consumed on the seafloor, acting as a geochemical switch that modulates Earth's climate, according to a research article published in the journal Nature Geoscience. The researchers of the study are from China.

articles.title: Reader's View: Remind your reps climate change is critical
articles.summary: Maggie Wineburgh-Freed, from Los Angeles, is concerned about climate change and the impact on food production. She believes the earth provides enough food now for everyone, even though its distribution leaves much to be desired. The world is changing and our children and grandchildren will take the brunt of it.

articles.title: Behind the story: Treasure Coast leaders saw 'crisis' coming in 2005. What happened?
articles.author: Laurence Reisman
articles.summary: Laurence Reisman covered numerous meetings of the Committee for a Sustainable Treasure Coast. 37 leaders from Martin, St. Lucie and Indian River counties met for 18 months in person to address a crisis foreseen in late 2003 by Sen. Ken Pruitt. Reisman spent several weeks reviewing the recommendations 20 years after the committee report came out.

articles.title: Coastal management options open for community consultation
articles.author: Lauren Evans
articles.summary: Newcastle's coastline is under threat from erosion and rising seas. Council wants to take a proactive approach to protect it before it's too late. Locals are being urged to have their say on how to best protect Newcastle's beloved coastline and give their opinion.

articles.title: Watch the trailer for unexpected sequel to Gerard Butler's 'surprisingly good' disaster thriller
articles.author: Digital Spy
articles.summary: Greenland 2: Migration is the sequel to Gerard Butler's 2020 disaster thriller "Migration". It's set to be released next year. Butler reprises his role as structural engineer John Garrity, who has to plot his new project. It's the first trailer has been released.

articles.title: PDRC Annual Peace Conference: Reflections on Climate Change, Peace, and Security in Somalia
articles.author: Hussien Mohamed
articles.summary: Hussien Mohamed Yusuf attended the Puntland Development and Research Center's Annual Peace Conference in Garowe. The conference focused on the theme 'Climate Change, Peace, and Security'. The conference brought together researchers, policy experts, and practitioners from across Somalia as well as colleagues from, Ethiopia, Kenya, Europe and the U.S. Hussien was on a panel discussion on water resources.

articles.title: Victims of Chantal fear more flooding could be on the way
articles.author: WRAL
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Chantal caused flooding in Chapel Hill, North Carolina. Another tropical storm is on the horizon, threatening to disrupt the rebuilding efforts there.    - local news reports.  - Local news reports that more flooding could be on the way.

articles.title: In front of drowning nations, Trump calls climate change a 'con job'
articles.author: Anniversary Issue-I
articles.summary: Trump's speech at the UN General Assembly on Tuesday was expansive and included false statements and connections between things that are not connected. Trump has long been a critic of climate science and polices aimed at helping the world transition to green energies like wind and solar. The three cheapest electricity sources globally last year were onshore wind, solar panels and new hydropower, according to an energy cost report by IRENA.

articles.title: Climate Criminal Australia's False Net Zero Plan To Deceive World & Pacific For COP31
articles.summary: The Australian Labor Government is lying by omission and by commission in its Net Zero Plan to deceive voters and the world. The world is threatened by nuclear weapons and climate change. Australia under Labor or the Coalition is a fervent supporter of nuclear terrorist America and of Apartheid Israel. A large proportion of Coalition MPs agree with absurdly anti-science President Donald Trump.

articles.title: Goa Braces for More Downpours: IMD Issues Yellow Alert
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Heavy downpours have engulfed various parts of Goa, including the capital city, Panaji, prompting the India Meteorological Department (IMD) to issue a 'yellow alert'. The alert forecasts continued intense showers over the coastal state for four days until October 1st. IMD warned of squally conditions with wind speeds reaching 40-50 km/h, gusting up to 60 kmph along the coast.

articles.title: Man arrested after attempting to evade police in dramatic shopping centre chase
articles.summary: Nine out of 10 Aussies admit to distracted driving. A further 30 per cent say they don't care about the road rules, according to a survey by the Australian National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (ANSTS).       .

articles.title: Meet the Scots pensioner keeping the Gaza aid flotilla sailing
articles.author: Derek Healey
articles.summary: Jim Griffin, 71, is travelling to Gaza as part of the Global Sumud Flotilla to deliver food and medical aid to starving Palestinians. He was supposed to be in Barcelona helping prepare boats, but organisers needed an engineer on board an old fishing vessel. The sea was rough from Barcelona and the conditions on board the boat are rough, but Jim is not scared.

articles.title: In front of drowning nations, Trump dismisses climate change as ‘con job'
articles.summary: US President Donald Trump called climate change a 'con job' at the UN General Assembly. Palau's ambassador and head of the group of small island states, Ilana Seid, said the rhetoric was expected but deeply concerning. Malawi's ambassador, Evans Davie Njewa, warned that we are endangering the lives of innocent people. Adelle Thomas, vice chair of the UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, recalled the devastation of Hurricane Sandy in 2012.

articles.title: Imelda may stall offshore resulting in heavy rain for the Midlands
articles.author: Will Rowe
articles.summary: Imelda is located in the northeast Caribbean and is forecast to push north into tomorrow. It's forecast to become a Category 1 hurricane by tomorrow afternoon. Imelda may make landfall over South Carolina on Monday night, moving inland near the Midlands early Tuesday. The best advice is to prepare for the worst case scenario.

articles.title: Wine to Water aids Hurricane Helene recovery efforts in North Carolina
articles.summary: Doc Hendley is the CEO and founder of Wine to Water. His organization is helping North Carolina communities one year after Hurricane Helene. He appeared on 'Fox & Friends Weekend' on Fox & Friends.      Â   "Wine to Water"

articles.title: Scientists discover serious flaw in predictions for major global crisis: 'Overestimated'
articles.author: Mandy Carr
articles.summary: A study conducted in Greenland shed new light on melting ice sheets. It is now believed that bare ice can act like firn ice, which is more porous, and snow. The climate models are not accounting for this, so they are overestimating ice sheet runoff. The Intergovernmental Panel estimates that the sea level will rise between 1.4 and 2.8 feet by 2100. The Carolinas are most at risk, since three North Carolina coastal counties would be submerged in water.

articles.title: Chapel Hill residents brace for soon to be tropical storm amid recovery from Chantal's devastation
articles.author: Kirstyn Clark
articles.summary: Tropical Depression Chantal brought severe flooding and damage to the area nearly three months ago. Many people lost everything and were forced to find temporary housing. The threat of more heavy rain and flooding in the coming days looms. Some residents are still waiting on funding and permanent housing.

articles.title: Scientists spot brand-new island created by powerful natural phenomenon — here's what's happening
articles.author: Calvin Coffee
articles.summary: Scientists at NASA have spotted a new island on Alaska's remote Alsek Lake. The glacier ice that once surrounded the island has melted away over decades of global warming. The new island is a clear sign of significant ice melt along the southeastern Alaskan coast. New lakes are emerging across the region, highlighting the larger dangers of melting glaciers.

articles.title: Fiji ready to host displaced islanders
articles.author: FBC News
articles.summary: Prime Minister Sitiveni Rabuka has called on global leaders to act urgently on climate change. He warns of rising seas due to climate change and warns of the threat posed by rising seas.    in his statement.  in this context, he also called for action on global warming.

articles.title: This Thursday: Stand up for our environment
articles.author: The Malta Independent
articles.summary: The past 12 years have been an assault on the environment in Malta. All aspects of the environment have changed in Malta, but not always for the better. Herbert Ganado and others agree that Malta has seen a change, but it hasn't always been a good one.

articles.title: Migration Begins As Autumn Arrives
articles.author: Charlotte Schmaltz
articles.summary: Audubon Community Center is located at Audubon Nature Center in Chautauqua County, New York. Autumnal Equinox has passed and the leaves are changing. Many animals are changing their patterns to prepare for the upcoming winter. In Western New York, several groups of animals will migrate, including birds, insects and even some amphibians.

articles.title: Chinese researchers identify new 'geochemical switch' regulating Earth's Climate
articles.summary: Shifts in marine sulfate concentrations can flip the way that methane is consumed on the seafloor. Earth endured an extreme period of global warming and ocean acidification, known as the Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum, 56 million years ago. The study highlights potential perturbations to Arctic carbon cycling under climate change.

articles.title: Agricultural damage from recent storms in Philippines nears 24 mln USD
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Tropical storm Mitag and super typhoon Ragasa have caused an estimated 1.38 billion pesos in damage and losses to the country's agricultural sector. Around 55,595 farmers and agricultural workers have been affected, with damage spanning 47,723 hectares of farmland. Preliminary estimates point to production losses of 109,997 metric tons.

articles.title: Migrating ticks raise disease risks if they can't be quickly tracked
articles.author: system
articles.summary: As climate change makes winters shorter, the time ticks spend active is increasing, so tracking them is more important now.    .   i.e. because of human-driven climate change, ticks spend more time active and their activity is increasing.

articles.title: Reader's View: Remind your reps climate change is critical
articles.author: Duluth News Tribune
articles.summary: Europe and the U.S. may see as much as a 40% decline in agricultural production due to climate change, according to the News Tribune's 'Local View' column in the Sept. 21 edition of the paper. Northland "paradise" doesn't fool you on climate change.

articles.title: Nadia Lim: 'If exercise was a pill, it would outdo any other pill out there'
articles.author: Stuff
articles.summary: After working outside on her high-country sheep station, the Kiwi chef-turned-farmer loves listening to rain on the roof and listening to a crackling fire next to a fire.   Â. Â   y
